post.author: Firesky7
post.title: /u/Firesky7 provides a peek into insider perspectives on oil spills

div.p: I haven't had visibility to the insides of all of your examples, but I did have an internship at BP post-Deepwater Horizon where the stories and attitudes do not align with the flippant "it's priced in" attitude that you describe.

The entire organization was terrified of another oil spill, saying multiple times that it almost bankrupted the company and forced them to sell off sections of the business (Arco gas stations have an incredibly wonky licensing structure as a result of this). While it's demonstrably possible for a company like BP to survive spills like Deepwater Horizon, they result in capital flows to completely unprofitable cleanup efforts, preventing investment in other wells and wrecking a lot of investment planning. In their estimation, BP was just starting to recover almost a decade later.
